chapter.title: Thumper Requirements
chapter.para: This chapter contains the requirements of the Thumper system. In this context "system" means both the client and the server programs. We begin by enumerating the high level security properties required by the system.

listitem.para: Client Soundness. The client should never claim to have received a valid time-stamp response when it did not. It is acceptable, although undesirable, for the client to incorrectly reject a valid response as invalid.
Server Soundness. The server should never produce a valid time-stamp in response to an invalid request.
Server Completeness. The server should always produce a valid time-stamp in response to a valid request.
Server Integrity. The server should always function according to specification regardless of the inputs it receives from clients.

Network Safety. The client and server should be able to resist all attacks possible by a Dolev-Yao attacker except for denial-of-services attacks implemented by removing (or delaying arbitrarily) messages sent over the network.
Lack of Information Leakage. The server never transmits any information pertaining to the private key except for the signatures generated by it.
Lack of Information Corruption. The server never writes to the private key either in memory or as stored on disk.

chapter.para: The system also makes one important security related assumption.

listitem.para: Server System Security. The server assumes that all files stored on the local file system are private to the server process (this includes the server's private key(s)). The server assumes the time returned by the local operating system is correct.

chapter.para: Notice that the client makes no (significant) security assumptions. As required by RFC-3161 the client verifies the form and content of any time-stamp returned by the server. Furthermore the protocol does not require the client to reveal the contents of the file being time-stamped nor provide any identifying information.

section.title: Functional Requirements
section.para: The client and server must implement the protocol detailed in RFC-3161 and its update RFC-5816. The public key of the server must be made available to the client, by a means not specified here, in the form of an X.509 v3 certificate as described in RFC-5280

RFC-3161 defines a number of optional transport methods for time-stamping messages. This version of Thumper is required to support a UDP based transport modelled after the "direct TCP transport" mechanism described in section 3.3 of RFC-3161. In particular only packets of type "tsaMsg" are to be accepted from the client and only responses of type "finalMsgRep" or "errorMsgRep" are to be generated by the server. No support for polling as defined in RFC-3161 is required. Additional transport mechanisms may be implemented as a future enhancement.

section.title: Non-Functional Requirements
section.para: The server should return time stamps as quickly "as possible." However this specification imposes no specific performance requirements. It is acknowledged that some applications of this protocol may require that time stamps be generated at high speed and/or for a large number of clients approximately simultaneously. Support for concurrent clients is not required but also is not forbidden by these requirements.
